sentence.text: Case 2 is the mother of Case 1.
She was well until the age of 18 when she began to have pain and weakness in her lower limbs that were aggravated by activity and stress.
The pain worsened at night and was only minimally relieved by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
At age 37 years she was diagnosed with PDD following the diagnosis of her son.
She had mild genua valga, pes planus, decreased strength in the proximal lower limbs, and a wide-based gait.
Her physical exam was otherwise normal.
Her calcium, phosphorus, and alkaline phosphatase were within normal limits.
Her roentgenograms showed hyperostosis of the femora, left tibia, left ulna, and skull.
The right tibia and right ulna were normal.
At age 47 years she presented with a severe episode of low back and right hip pain with difficulty in walking.
She was taking up to 3,900 mg/day of aspirin.
Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) was 108 mm/h (normal < 20 mm/h), and an antinuclear antibody test was reported positive; the titer was not documented.
She was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus.
She was treated with 15 mg/day of prednisone with rapid resolution of her symptoms.
At age 48 years, she reported a 10 month history of aches in her thighs requiring bed rest 2–3 days a week.
She was receiving weekly cortisone injections and taking carisoprodol/aspirin and acetaminophen.
She had 4/5 strength in the proximal muscles of the upper and lower limbs.
The electromyogram (EMG) findings were suggestive of myopathic changes in the proximal muscles of the upper and lower limbs.
A muscle biopsy from the left deltoid was normal.
She was diagnosed with polymyositis and treated with 15 mg/day of prednisone.
She continued to have pain that was treated with aspirin, acetaminophen, and occasional oxycodone with aspirin.
She developed decreased range of motion at the ankles, tenderness to palpation over the lower limbs, hyperactive reflexes, and patellar clonus.
Radiographs showed slightly widened bone shafts.
No new bones were involved.
At age 73 years, she reported a 4-year history of left hip and low back pain associated with several falls, in addition to episodes of vertigo, headache, and tinnitus that lasted for several days.
On exam she had thoracic kyphosis and lumbar lordosis.
The ESR was normal.
A head CT scan showed skull hyperostosis with involvement of the internal auditory canals.
